150602315.review: Pony Island engaña con su apariencia inicial de un juego sobre ponis, revelándose rápidamente como una experiencia oscura y llena de giros. Me fascina cómo rompe la cuarta pared, combinando puzzles y plataformas con una narrativa meta. Es inquietante y surrealista, simple en diseño pero profundamente efectivo. En resumen, Pony Island es una experiencia única en el mundo de los videojuegos, perfecta para quienes buscan algo totalmente fuera de lo común.

150538150.review:
[h1] Introduccion [/h1]
 
lo habia encontrado en rebaja y habia visto varios videos sobre el juego y por el precio decide darle la oportunidad mas que nada por que soy bastante fan de este tipo de juegos que rompen la cuarta pared y con unas reseñas muy buenas tome la decision de comprarlo.

[h1] Argumento [/h1]

en poco tiempo descubrimos que el juego está corrompido por el mismo Lucifer, quien está tratando de reclamar el alma del jugador(nosotros) para sí mismo. Somos ayudados por el alma de un jugador anterior a acceder a la programación interna de Pony Island para sortear las trampas dejadas por Lucifer y salvar no solo su alma, sino las muchas almas atormentadas que están atrapadas dentro del código del juego.


[h1] Jugabilidad [/h1]

Pony Island tiene la tipica jugabilidad tosca de un juego de arcade. Es principalmente un estilo de apuntar y hacer clic, en algunos momentos usamos una  especie de sistema operativo simulado. debemos explorar la programación interna del juego de arcade «Pony Island» para poder ir progresando. A veces, debemos jugar «Pony Island», un tipo de juego que consiste en correr sin fin, guiando a un poni a través de un valle cubierto de hierba, evitando obstáculos y disparando a los enemigos. así como del sistema operativo, haciendo clic en los «portales» que aparecen en la pantalla, presentandonos un pseudocódigo simplificado junto con uno o más cuadros y comandos de instrucciones visuales, como «mover hacia abajo», «mover a la izquierda» o «repetir». En estas pantallas, nosotros deberemos reordenar las instrucciones visuales para modificar cómo se ejecutará la «programación». Esto evitará cualquier «corrupción» en el código del juego o, en algunos casos, «engañará» al juego (por ejemplo, aumentando sus puntos de experiencia) para poder avanzar, en pocas palabras serian una especie de puzzles. La persona con la que nosotros hablamos dentro del juego a través de mensajes crea portales a los archivos principales, con los que se puede interactuar. En una parte del juego, hay cuatro personas, incluido Nosotros: «1U©iF#r» (el Diablo), «CORRUPTED», «h0peles$0ul», y tú, el «Guest»

[h1] Graficos [/h1]

desarrollado por Unity no podemos hablar mucho del apartado grafico siendo un juego 2D y que recrea un juego arcade de muchos años atras, aunque el juego se ve bastante bien para ser que no busca exactamente tener buenos graficos 7,5/10

[h1] Sonido [/h1]

no tenemos dialogos en si solo ruidos y textos pero en ni un momento tenemos algun dialogo, los sonidos son simples y bonitos con el ambiente del juego los sonidos le queda perfecto, es un juego que no hace falta dialogos con los textos es mas que suficiente 8,5/10

[h1] 100% [/h1]

Su 100% la verdad es bastante facil entre 6/9 horas tranquilamente podemos terminarlo para la primera pasada les recomiendo jugar al juego y disfrutar su historia despues pueden
sacar los logros tiene logros simples y un logro de coleccionar tickets que son en total 24 tickets el cual tambien nos desbloquea un final secreto.
 Les dejo la guia la cual use para sacar todos los logros y asi no se les dificulta encontrar todos los tickets que la verdad no estan tan dificiles en dos pasadas obtendran el 100%

https://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=845486718
[h1] Conclusion [/h1]

Pony island es el tipico juego que rompe la 4ta pared pero de la manera en que lo hace es bastante unico y un juego que lo que tiene de malo es la poca duracion que tiene en una tarde tranquilamente lo podemos terminar de manera facil por eso pienso que lo unico malo del juego es su corta duracion, su precio la verdad vale la pena(EN ARG NO) y mas si lo conseguimos en descuento, Pony island es mas que nada para a los que les gusta este tipo de juegos, Tiene buen sonido para el ambiente que tiene el juego y un apartado grafico simple pero como dijimos anteriormente la base del juego no es su su apartado grafico ya que jugamos un juego de arcade viejo, para los fanes de juegos indie este es un juego que tienen que tener en sus colecciones.

NOTA FINAL : 8/10

[h1]The Gameplay: [/h1]
Very fun puzzle game where you have to think on your feet. It is fun and intuitive, may remind you of the Stanly Parable in that you have a lot of agency in how the game progresses.

[h1]The Story:[/h1]
I mean, there is something, but I am not sure I would constitute it as a story more so than a setting with some consequences. None the less, it is an entertaining setting.

[h1]The Visuals:[/h1]
This is a strength of the game, while not using realistic graphics or anything, it manages to keep a certain style and is not afraid to explore outside of that.

[h1]The Sound:[/h1]
The music is one of it's strong points using the 8-16 bit music to great effect.


[h1]The Experience:[/h1]
Its hard to describe the experience without spoiling how the game works. It is very good and requires you to think outside the box, to think meta. Its short, but very sweet and definitely worth its price. Big recommended on this game.

148034621.review:
Pony Island is a devilishly charming video game that puts a refreshing spin on the videogame possessed-by-the-devil trope. While the gameplay may lack depth, it compensates with its unique aesthetic, tantalizing secrets, and delightfully offbeat tone. All you have to do is interact with shady interfaces, play silly java-style games and solve easy puzzles.

The game purposefully leaves many mysteries unsolved, inviting fans to speculate and connect the dots themselves. It's a very short adventure, lacking in replayability, but completionists will be rewarded handsomely.

Overall, Pony Island offers a pleasant ride filled with its own distinct flavor, even if it doesn't delve too deeply.

146252914.review:
Very interesting and innovative game. 

Whereas I can’t say that I had fun playing it (I really didn’t) I can’t help but appreciate the thoughts that went into it. 
Some of its puzzle/investigative elements are quite great, but then it throws in a lot of, at best, boring and tedious levels (the Pony levels), which, at worst – and towards the end of the game, are so frustrating to play that I came close to quitting the game for good. Especially because it doesn’t just require learning the mechanics and using them well, but also to be lucky (as they are randomly generated, meaning sometimes you get an easy run and sometimes you have to go through 5 relatively unfair attempts before getting one that feels fair. 

And can I recommend it? Not sure. I did not enjoy it, but I just feel like I have to praise the ingenuity whether I found it entertaining or not. 

So yeah, didn’t love it, but I don’t hate it and it is conceptually cool. Very cool.

I regret not playing this game earlier, because in 2023 the novelty of a postmodern indie game that attempts to mess with the player's head by questioning what "is" and "isn't" part of the game... kind of wore off now. Carried on the wings of Undertale's popularity, we really got it good now, huh?

But to be fair, Pony Island holds its own well in this regard. Mostly because it accepts still being a video game after all, and isn't afraid of walking a fine line between "sillly" and "scary". I mean, the very premise... look, let's put it this way. In this game you face Satan himself, who in this reality is a crappy game developer trying to gather souls through microtransactions and shareware in his terrible products. I love the concept, just imagining the lord of hell hastily adjusting his hackjob code in the middle of you playing - he's even being really polite about it! Okay, most of the time. At the end of the day, you still have to break everything, there is no other route around it (and that's fine).

Because of the premise, gameplay isn't really all that sophisticated, but it's surprisingly good. Navigating the system is kind of like a point n click game, you're rewarded for your keen eye as you look for details and pay attention to chat dialogue. The "actual" Pony Island game is an endless runner of sorts, just very simple. But I think the best part are the puzzle segments with coding (and, uh, butterflies). Starts very basic, but quickly builds up into REALLY testing your brain. That last puzzle is an absolute monster, and even after beating it twice I still can't tell you how I did it, and looking up videos online of others trying to provide a solution showed to me that I'm not alone in that impression.

Visuals are easy to trivialize as run of the mill faux-retro pixel art, but if you soldier on and pass at least the first act, it's easy to see that that's not really the case - it's a conscious direction to convey the setting. Certain scenes clearly show that yes, the creator(s?) of the game CAN do good graphics, it's just that Lucifer isn't too hot at it. Music, however, though often absent in favor of an ominous humming of the game cabinet, is pretty solid all over. It's comforting to know that at the very least, the devil is decent at making chiptunes (unless they're stolen lol).

Lastly, I really like how many secrets are hidden here, despite Pony Island's short length. There's an additional thing to do at just about every corner, and a lot of these serve to expand on the plot in a cool way (or make a reference to the opening of Malcolm in the Middle, which is cool too I guess). However, just like Undertale, this game also will make you question if 100%ing the game is the right thing to do... but fortunately isn't as harsh and unforgiving about it. Again, at the end of the day it's still a game, so I actually like this approach better (and yes I did 100% it). Though maybe because of its short length, I found it hard to care about the characters.

Still, it was a fun experience and even though indie gaming has seen a lot of similar stuff in this age, I nonetheless recommend you try it too. Pony Island still manages to remain quite unique.

145543180.review:
i review games on steam after i 100% complete them! check out my reviews to see all the games i have completed!

pony island is best described as a point-and-click adventure, and was developed and published by daniel mullins. it's his first game published to steam, and he went on to make the hex (2018) and inscryption (2021). pony island was released in january 2016 on PC platforms. development begun in december 2014 when mullins started working on the game for a 48-hour game jam. it was considered one of the better games at the game jam and eventually he got the game published to steam in 2016.  it's mostly presented as a arcade cabinet that you play, but in addition to playing the actual game, you also explore the internal programming of said arcade cabinet as odd things begin to happen.. it's very convoluted and complex as far as gameplay goes. i won't spoil any major details, so i will avoid going into detail on the story/plot, but just know there is extremely good writing in this game. there's a lot of mystery and intrigue as you play through the game, and while it can be extremely confusing, it's also a delight to play through in a silent and dark room at night. i have seen critics/reviewers claim pony island is "psychological horror done right" and while i don't think it went that far, it does a good job at being off-putting enough to make players uncomfortable as they're playing it. 

this was a brilliant introduction to daniel mullins, and i personally cannot wait to eventually delve into his future works, as the hex and inscryption both seem like massive upgrades on this already great package. i always see that it's on sale for 80% off, making this only a dollar for what is an extremely great little gem of a video game. you won't play anything like it elsewhere, and probably never will.

The game's incorporation of glitches and glitches within glitches adds an extra layer of intrigue. 143480874.review:
The game is only interesting on a very superficial level for all of its meta-ness. The actual gameplay is extremely boring. For a 2 hour game, it is repetitive and simplistic. 90% of the game is doing the same thing over and over: running in a very simplistic platformer with frustrating gimmicks. 10% of the game is decent logic puzzles, but because they are thrown at you, it's hard to really enjoy them for what they are. 

The game is tied together in a really simplistic and annoying narrative, with text that moves frustratingly slow, and you cannot fast forward. The Lucifer/666 stuff is over the top to the point where it seems childish and hamfisted, rather than being creepy, spooky, or even interesting at all. More like a middle school kid's idea of a joke.

It wasn't a horrible game, but it was by no means a good game. The best I can say about it is that it was mildly interesting. I would only recommend it if you're *really* interested, and even then consider getting it on sale.

141248119.review:
Pony Island certainly left an impression, albeit I wished its story didn’t involve the diabolical elements that it does. Despite this, it does manage to tell it well and its efforts at breaking the fourth wall did produce some disconcerting moments for me.

It’s a game full of creative ideas, insinuations, secrets, metaphors, and eerie moments. The kind of game that questions the whole concept of what a game is and redefines its relation to the player. At times you feel like it is playing you instead of the other way around.

I still can’t bring myself to wholeheartedly recommend this game, but if you’re interested in a different kind of approach to game design and can’t help yourself, I can’t stop you. I’m just a text review. Or am I?

[b]Rating: 65/100[/b]

If you're interested in Puzzle- or semi horror games, I'd recommend it a lot.

139400616.review:
After playing Inscryption, I went back to play more of Daniel Mullins' games. With Pony Island, you can see the genius that led to Inscryption (one of my favorite games of all time). 

The humor is especially strong in this one--I LOLed quite a bit. My favorite gag was [spoiler] "You killed Jesus!"  bwahahaha [/spoiler]. Like other games in what I loosely call the "fourth wall breaking" genre (see: This Is Not a Game, Stanley Parable, Liminal), this game never lets you forget that you are playing a game, with the purpose being to destroy the game as you are playing it. The use of Jesus/Lucifer was fun, although I think Mullins did well in getting rid of the religious iconography and moving into a more fantasy direction with Inscryption. 

At one point, the game did a total gotcha! to me--I was 100% startled. For those who've already played: [spoiler] When it pretended to be a friend on my Steam Friends' list, I literally closed the game and went into my Steam privacy settings, because I was freaked out that anyone could be watching me play a game. When I realized it was a trick, I shook my head in chagrin. He did something similar in Inscryption, but I'd forgotten it was possible! [/spoiler].

There's a distinct quality to Mullins' games that I haven't found anywhere else--a wry sarcasm, a humor that plays on gamers' expectations for a game. It's oddly comforting. Unlike so many other games, you can't predict what's going to happen next, and what does happen is usually something you would never, in a million years, have considered. The creativity and originality of it is mind-boggling.  

If you dig indie gems, try this one (and Inscryption, obvs).

138611865.review:
Pony Island is a peculiar and unconventional indie game that takes players on a mind-bending journey unlike anything else. With its unique blend of genres, unexpected twists, and distinctive presentation, Pony Island captivates players from start to finish, leaving them contemplating its enigmatic charm. While not without a few minor hiccups, it is undoubtedly an experience worth undertaking, earning a solid score of 4/5.

At first glance, Pony Island appears to be a simple and innocent arcade game featuring adorable ponies. However, beneath its seemingly innocent exterior lies a dark and twisted narrative that unfolds in ways you could never anticipate. The game takes pleasure in subverting expectations, constantly challenging and engaging players with its clever puzzles and unconventional mechanics.

The gameplay of Pony Island is refreshingly unique. It blends elements of classic arcade games with puzzle-solving and a touch of meta-narrative. Maneuvering through the glitchy and glitch-filled levels, you'll encounter obstacles, riddles, and unexpected surprises that keep you on your toes. The way Pony Island subverts traditional gameplay conventions and breaks the fourth wall is a stroke of genius, creating a truly immersive experience.

The storytelling in Pony Island is where the game truly shines. It cleverly weaves a mysterious and thought-provoking narrative that keeps you engaged throughout. The way it incorporates themes of technology, mythology, and existentialism is intriguing, often leaving players questioning the nature of their own reality. The game's plot twists and unexpected revelations are delivered with finesse, providing a memorable and satisfying experience.

Visually, Pony Island employs a retro aesthetic that pays homage to the classic arcade era. The pixel art style, combined with glitch effects and eerie atmosphere, creates a distinct and memorable ambiance. The sound design complements the visuals perfectly, with a haunting and atmospheric soundtrack that enhances the game's overall tone.

While Pony Island is a remarkable experience, it does have a few minor shortcomings. Some puzzles and mechanics may feel repetitive after a while, and a few segments could benefit from further refinement to maintain a consistent level of engagement. However, these minor flaws are overshadowed by the game's overall uniqueness and creativity.

In conclusion, Pony Island is an indie gem that pushes the boundaries of traditional gaming. Its unconventional narrative, inventive gameplay mechanics, and distinctive visual style make it a captivating and memorable experience. With its intriguing twists and thought-provoking themes, Pony Island stands as a shining example of indie game innovation. While it may not be perfect, its charm and originality make it an absolute must-play for those seeking something out of the ordinary.

Score: 4/5

135561309.review:
Ingredientes:

6 choclos grandes
1 cebolla mediana picada en cubos pequeños
1/2 taza de aceite vegetal
1/2 taza de leche
1 cucharada de sal
1/2 cucharadita de comino
1/4 cucharadita de pimienta
Instrucciones:

Desgrana los choclos y licúalos junto con la leche, la sal, el comino y la pimienta. Debe quedar una mezcla homogénea y sin grumos.
En una sartén grande, sofríe la cebolla en el aceite hasta que esté dorada.
Agrega la mezcla de choclo a la sartén y revuelve constantemente a fuego medio-bajo hasta que espese. Esto puede tardar entre 30 a 40 minutos.
Una vez que la mezcla haya espesado, retira del fuego y deja enfriar.
Mientras tanto, prepara las hojas de choclo. Pela las hojas de choclo con cuidado y corta en cuadrados del mismo tamaño.
Coloca una cucharada grande de la mezcla de choclo en el centro de una hoja de choclo y envuelve formando un paquete. Asegúrate de que quede bien cerrado.
Coloca los paquetes en una olla grande con agua hirviendo y cocina durante 45 minutos.
Una vez que estén cocidas, saca las humitas del agua y déjalas enfriar antes de servir.
¡Y listo! Ya tienes unas deliciosas humitas para compartir en familia o con amigos. ¡Que las disfrutes!

130835827.review:
This will indeed be an interesting review, as I had purchased this game in an Inscryption bundle with absolutely no knowledge of the game in advance. So, with absolutely no idea or preconceptions, I opened up Pony Island. Here's a few non-spoilery feelings about it.

Really Good: If you enjoyed the mind of Daniel Mullins in a game like Inscryption, you'll love the overall feel of the game. The plot points feel like something you would expect from on of Daniel's games, and that's not a bad thing at all. The mood and the personality of the game were pretty cool. DM's trademark dark humor and attention to detail is here. I really liked the very very end. (no spoilers)

The Kinda Good: I really enjoyed the puzzles (at first - more on this later) and felt that going through the code of the game was quite interesting. The gameplay was easy to learn and understand (more on this later, too!). 

The "ugh": The puzzles become very repetitive towards the end. While the puzzle idea is novel, and the puzzles offer a nice degree of challenge, they become a chore towards the end, and I rolled my eyes when I had to play them. Luckily, this only happened towards the end of the run. The gameplay was perfectly fine, and while I realize the importance of (basically) repeating the same thing over and over again, it didn't make for a really satisfying game play.

The "I wish": I know this game came out nearly 7 years ago. I firmly believe that Daniel, knowing what he knows now, would be able to make this game an absolutely legendary game. 

On its own, it's definitely worth a punt, especially if you're a fan of Daniel Mullins or you don't mind interesting puzzles (that may get a bit repetitive towards the end). Recommended with a caveat.

If you're into long, full, complex games, this probably isn't for you. But if you can enjoy a little gimmicky experience, I would recommend this.

130602903.review:
Like pretentious games? Like being fooled by the tag "Psychological Horror"? Like being tricked this is one of those games that fuck with you like When the darkness comes or (it's lesser doublet) Stanley Parable? Well spoiler, this ain't. After you strip away the pretentiousness (better use a spatula, or a blowtorch...), it's a basic mini-game collection with a lot of annoying parts (especially that last butterfly puzzle and the Beelzebub fight that NEEDS TO HAVE A FUCKING HEALTH METER) you really don't want to play in the year 20XX (hell the Atari 2600 had better games than the minigames in this one, and with a scoring system too). The story is passable, but certainly nothing special – and that's the real downfall of this game. For a story like e.g. Portal, I am willing to suffer through bad and boring gameplay (the gameplay in Portal did inded get really old and annoying in the second one, for the record), but not for something that turns more nondescript and generic the longer it goes on. Pony or Satan (who only spouts some generic platitudes and can't even be called a character despite being the vague villain of this game), nothing means anything to me or leaves any impression on me here! And of course, there's the tiresome "collect tickets hidden literally everywhere in the game" achievement that forces you to replay the game if you actually want to experience it for yourself the first time you play it (like I as a gamer usually do – minus the overly hard puzzles that would take away too much of my time and brain cells) and not just follow the guide to a T the first time (which definitely is the better strategy for the true achievement hunter). That would be ok if this game had replay value... but yeah... nope.

Despite what I said, this would still be a sideways thumb if Steam allowed that, as the structure of the game is still pretty creative (though the "pony" trope is everything but), but alas, as Steam is as black and white as [insert political comparison relating to America in the 2010s+ here] it's a thumb down. Truly a sign of the times.

Btw, I would've been literally stuck on the "text adventure" screen cause I didn't know how to go back to the menu, and apparently (unlike in ANY actual text adventure ever made, or DOS for that matter), you cannot have the screen repeat itself so you can see the list of commands again) if I hadn't looked up the situation in a video guide. Your call whether that's a "Did not do the research", or "Did they even test this game before they released it?" Thank Satan for creating the internet...

PS: Do try out When the darkness comes. It's got the scariest moment I ever experienced sitting in front of a computer screen...

125216444.review:
Pony Island se presenta como un juego de plataformas aparentemente inocente y colorido protagonizado por un adorable pony. Sin embargo, rápidamente se convierte en una experiencia mucho más profunda y surrealista. El jugador se encontrará desafiado a resolver puzles ingeniosos, interactuar con el propio sistema del juego y sumergirse en una narrativa meta que trasciende los límites de la pantalla.

Narrativa y atmósfera:
La narrativa de Pony Island es uno de los aspectos más fascinantes del juego. A medida que el jugador avanza, se descubre una historia oscura y retorcida, llena de giros sorprendentes y momentos desconcertantes. La trama se construye cuidadosamente para mantener al jugador en suspenso y preguntándose qué está sucediendo realmente en el mundo del juego. La cuarta pared se rompe de manera creativa y constante, añadiendo capas adicionales de intriga a medida que la narrativa se adentra en temas existenciales y filosóficos.

El juego logra una atmósfera inquietante y opresiva, gracias a su estilo visual y sonoro. El diseño gráfico combina elementos retro con efectos visuales sorprendentes que juegan con la percepción del jugador, mientras que la música acompaña perfectamente la atmósfera, alternando entre melodías encantadoras y tonos oscuros y perturbadores.

Jugabilidad y diseño de niveles:
La jugabilidad de Pony Island está compuesta por una serie de ingeniosos rompecabezas y desafíos de plataformas que deben superarse para avanzar en la historia. La mecánica del juego se mezcla con la narrativa, creando una experiencia inmersiva y única que desafía constantemente al jugador a pensar de manera creativa y fuera de lo convencional. Cada nivel presenta nuevos obstáculos y sorpresas, manteniendo la frescura y la emoción en cada etapa.

Originalidad y metaficción:
Pony Island es un ejemplo sobresaliente de metaficción en los videojuegos. A través de su narrativa y mecánicas de juego, el juego desafía la noción tradicional de lo que es un videojuego y cuestiona la realidad misma. La originalidad radica en cómo se mezclan los diferentes géneros y elementos, así como en la forma en que el juego involucra activamente al jugador en la experiencia y la historia.

Conclusión:
Pony Island es un título imprescindible para aquellos que buscan una experiencia de juego fuera de lo común. Con una narrativa intrigante, una atmósfera inquietante y una jugabilidad innovadora, el juego lleva al jugador a un viaje surrealista y filosófico que desafía las expectativas. Su originalidad, ingenio y capacidad para sumergir al jugador en un mundo desconcertante lo convierten en un videojuego que deja una impresión duradera y que será recordado como una obra maestra de la metaficción en el mundo de los videojuegos.

125202468.review:
Pony Island is a weird but brilliant game where you try to escape an arcade machine. Gameplay mostly consists of exploration, 2D running sections and puzzles. It has more tricks, but I can’t spoil more than this. It reminded me of Undertale on how it usually breaks the 4th wall.
It is a great little indie title full of surprises. It also has hidden stuff to find for collectables and extra achievements, although you’ll need a guide for 100% completion. But there’s a chapter selection after beating the game to speed that up.
It’s an easy recommendation, even at full price, despite not being too long. It has a very clever design, so props to the devs for this gem.

This game seems to be an elaborate joke.

The joke is that the gameplay is incredibly tedious.

The main parts of the actual gameplay are a very basic programming-style puzzle where you drag arrows around to redirect a pointer, but mostly you can brute-force it, plus a terrible auto-running thing where you have to jump gates and shoot enemies. I would say it would be at home on a Game & Watch but that would be an insult to Game & Watch.

The quirky story and meta-narratives are not enough to make this anything other than a very tedious experience. The run & jump sections aren't actually challenging, they're very easy, but you will probably misjudge a jump at some point and get sent back to the start, at which point you'll think "Whelp, now I have to do this crap again".

Just don't bother, the payoff isn't at all worth it.

124467073.review:
Pony Island is extremely fun and in my opinion a hidden gem. A puzzle adventure game, with multiple layers and an abundance of hidden easter eggs - all accompanied by many achievements.

On the surface it is a runner game, booted up on an old arcade machine owned by the devil himself. You are set forth with discovering who you are/were and destroying said machine.

The soundtrack is amazing and the sound effects do not pose as annoyingly repetitive. The art style is adorable, with multiple changes throughout the game. Game is split into multiple acts, each with its own unique take. Main controls are 
 your mouse, although you are confronted with an interactive chat which helped to completely break the fourth wall and immerse yourself within the game.

Pony Island was not too difficult and is easily completed within 2-3 hours. Pony Island could be seen as somewhat repetitive at times, although each act has a fresh new look. I went back and thoroughly played through to ensure I found all the tickets, and any hidden easter eggs - this is also well catered to as you have access to each individual act/boss fight which prevents you from having to restart the entire game to gain certain achievements. Achievements are mostly easily obtainable apart from the hidden ones. The game does not require you to do any grinding for the achievements.

Labelled as a horror, it does have certain horror elements although would not call it horror. From the beginning of the game, up until the end, your expectations are completely unpredictable as the game is consistently evolving. The cheap price tag that comes with this gem, compared to the large amounts of mass produced asset-flips on the Steam store with a dearer price - makes this game a must buy. I thoroughly enjoyed it and was hooked in one sitting, going into my favourites for sure.

123648295.review:
[h1]İ̸̪̤̕t̶̝̙̆'̸̡̥͋͂s̵̛̤ ̷̾͜ͅȃ̴͖ ̸̰̔u̵̯͌ǹ̸̝ị̶̝̈́c̴̭̠̊͝o̶̝͔͂r̸͚̊̚͜n̸͇͇͐[/h1]
Pony Island is at large an unassuming platformer involving a titular pony, hopping merrily over wooden fences. It’s the fact that the game runs on an arcade machine possessed by the devil himself that earns its horror tag. “Works as intended” phrase is quickly put in unique context as the game twists and bends to the whim of a moody influence behind it. While mild in its fear factor, Pony Island is full of unorthodox creativity and delivers its ideas with truly impressive ingenuity. Curiosity of what the devs came up with next is enough to keep the player seated throughout the game’s runtime.
[url]https://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=2873715716[/url]
[b][i]ERMAC[/i] wins[/b]
One would struggle to find a better caption regarding Pony Island than the one present on the game’s own store page – “It is not a game about ponies”. While keeping things as ambiguous as humanly possible, it conveys the core idea of the game. The fence-jumping pony is merely a point of reference, used to show the player a game that twists and falls apart as the story progresses. The true gameplay would be solving a set of puzzles portraying the player’s interference with the Pony Island’s code, that while making the progress possible, also makes it increasingly unstable. Well, the title being possessed may also have something to do with that particular aspect.

While some may find the game’s distorted imagery slightly unnerving, its horror elements are downright negligible. To my eyes Pony Island is foremost a love letter to glitches. In a faraway land of the 90’s, when games often pushed technological boundaries of their respective systems, their capacity for short-lived or even one-time issues was substantial. Without widespread internet to patch the thing or distribute the news, these glitches often had an air of mystery surrounding them. Was it a simple error, or perhaps a hidden character in your favourite fighting game, whose means of unlocking are yet to be discovered? More than anything else, Pony Island pays a tribute to glitches’ role in creating gaming’s own set of urban legends. A nod to something nowadays almost entirely lost to technological advancement.

[b]Settings>Advanced Settings>Enable Free Will[/b]
Reference-laced gameplay would be more than enough to fill the game’s roughly 3-hours long runtime, yet this title goes on an extra mile with a layer of delightfully self-conscious humour worked into it. As it evolves throughout its playtime, Pony Island continuously toys around with its own formula in increasingly creative fashion (nausea-inducing Pony 3D blew me away). Furthermore, this title smuggles in more than a few jabs at both notion of the game development and how the player’s interaction with the game gives a meaning and context to its message. Pony Island pitches a couple of thought-provoking ideas if you are willing to read into it a little, turning this title into something much more universal than a throwback to glitches in old games could ever hope to be.
[url]https://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=2873716030[/url]
All things considered, this game squarely earns its demonic pony/10 rating. While not scary at all, it’s an enjoyable piece of human creativity, neatly wrapped to be downed in a spare evening. If you have any long-lived relationship with games or happen to have an interest in video games as a medium, I can’t recommend Pony Island enough. If you don’t meet any of these conditions, hats off to you. I wouldn’t expect you to come across this game at all, let alone read its lengthy review.

121773384.review:
Este juego sin duda es una experiencia muy extraña, una combinación de juegos de rompecabezas con juegos de corredores (runners) que me hace pensar en los problemas que tienen a veces los programadores cuando las cosas empiezan a fallar por cuestiones desconocidas, algo que quien ha trabajado programando sabe que es tristemente mas común de lo que uno quisiera admitir.

Aun jugandolo la historia que esta detras del juego es extraña, existen varios "niveles" de realidad donde se lleva a cabo el juego. Primero existe "Pony Island" que es el juego que jugamos en la pantalla frente a nosotros, esta la propia pantalla que vemos el cual contiene pony island y el contacto con otros personajes de la historia, pero esa pantalla esta enmarcada en un aparato que no es un simple adorno, aparte de la pantalla se encuentra insinuado una realidad fuera de esa pantalla que en momentos se logra ver que pareciera un salon de arcade  y por ultimo al final se revela una ultima rotura de la 4ta pared para concluir definitivamente con el juego. La forma en que esta diseñada la trama da mas interrogantes que respuestas, pero eso hace que sea mas interesante el pensar en que ese purgatorio creato para peleadores de las cruzadas obliga a los caballeros a jugar malos video juegos por toda la eternidad hasta que se rindan y otorgen su alma al demonio... o alguna otra tonteria por el estilo.

Otra cosa que podria decir es que aun que muchos de los puzzles parecieran acertijos de programación, no los considero completamente como tales ya que las direcciones para guiar las instrucciones no recuerdo ningun programa que se maneje de forma similar, aun que supongo que es una proximación de las funciones que mas adelante se ven como el "go to" o el portal morado. Pero en si dudo que alguien mejore en su habilida de programación con este juego, aun que alguien que sepa programar tal vez se le facilite mas por tener una estructura familiar.

Sin duda esta es una experiencia bastante experimental que me alegra haber probrado, aun que es dificil decir a que clase de persona podria recomendarselo, ¿Amantes de los rompecabezas, de los ponis, de demonios? Quizas la gente simplemente deba darle la oportunidad a ciegas.

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=PfMjmGQlinA

[*]- To pass 100% of achievements - you can't do without a guide[/list]

[b]Total:[/b]
A simple runner game in which we control a Pony. The horse gallops forward, shoots lasers from its eyes and has a pair of wings to overcome obstacles in its path. Several types of opponents that will keep you company. And corporate humor from the author of the fashionable (at the moment) "Inscryption".
You are inside Satan's slot machine - try to survive and get out of there. Preferably without losing your soul along the way...
The game is recommended for fans of "Inscryption", creepy-pastes and modern children's horror stories.

Daniel Mullins with another top-tier game about a lovely pink pony on a little island. Almost immediately, things get more interesting than a pink pony as the game blends text puzzling and side-scrolling with DOS-style graphics. Okay, honestly, i was expecting more from this game, especially this genre. But I've probably played a little too much of these and the element of surprise is long gone. The mind blowing part of the game seems a bit less even close to 0 for me, but there's still humor that made me laugh so I can say i still enjoy it nonetheless. The platforming (shooting?) part is pretty mediocre in both difficulty and stage setup so, they kinda felt a bit too easy for veteran platformer, but probably just right for amateur player so I can't say it's bad either. The Chat AI of the game isn't great and very unresponsive, which made the whole type your own question and sentence thing looks.. extra and needless. And speaking of extra, the Secret Ending really seemed like an "extra" entertain just to get the completionist to delete the game a.s.a.p... which... imo.. is a well done expression. Especially with the expressionless last boss. lol!

For those who haven't played a lot of this genre, i bet you can still get quite a lot of mind blowing surprise from it. For those who played a lot of this genre, this will come out as a "meh" game... for completionist, the hidden stuffs are still fun to find and collect, as well as getting that secret ending after all that work is rewarding(?)

Also, there's a bug that disable certain keys like Enter and Backspace on our keyboard if we have a controller/gamepad plugged in. One that made the game completely unplayable because we will get stuck at the stage where we need to type out the answers. Although unplugging the controller and restarting the game fixed it. This type of ridiculous bug shouldn't really exist in the first place.

116830216.review: Wanted to play Inscryption so thought I'd get the first two Daniel Mullins games to get some ideas of how he operates. :) Pleased to say that this is a brilliant game and I really don't want to spoil anything. Narratively, it's similar to There Is No Game: Wrong Dimension - you spend most of the game 'hacking' into a video game that has been coded by the Devil, meaning basic pony jumping games (sounds better than it is), then pseudo-code puzzles to proceed. An unsettling script helps to reinforce the atmosphere of being trapped in a possessed computer. The very best point in the game is towards the end during the final boss fight when he simply asks you to just focus on him, easy right? First two rounds I never took my eyes off him and passed the tests, then it breaks the fourth wall and had me genuinely worried that I had done something outside of the game that was going to make me no friends....attention lost, as I try to tab out of the game - I'm dead - awesome, really had me for a few minutes. Great little game.

116442750.review:
[i]Quien diría que un juego de ponis se iba a tornar tan extraño y de plano satánico, veamos de que va Pony Island y tratar de liberar tu alma.[/i]

-----
[h1]+Contexto del juego: [/h1]
[list]
[*]Desarrollado y distribuido por Daniel Mullins Games, Pony island es uno de sus primeros títulos creados por ellos, que tras un game jam y la ayuda de streamers, el estudio pudo sacar a lucir su título, además de no parar, siguiendo con el desarrollo de The Hex y el reciente Inscryption. La compañía está en sus primeros años, quien sabe lo que tendremos en un futuro cercano.
[/list]

[h1]+Historia: [/h1]
[list]
[*]Controlamos a una persona que se encuentra en el limbo, directamente se pondrá a jugar Pony Island, un juego de arcade un tanto curioso, porque parece no estar terminado. 
[*]La historia es un tanto simple, pero el como es contada, he ahí la magia del título, el juego constantemente te plantea varias cuestiones, búsqueda de información y decisiones, siempre hay nuevas opciones por las cuales expandir la historia.
[*]Algo importante es que el titulo hace muchas alusiones al ocultismo, así que si alguien es sensible a estos temas quizá el titulo no sea de su agrado. De mi parte, siento que solo juguetea con estos conceptos, no es extremo con las referencias al señor de las 3am.
[/list]

[h1]+Gameplay: [/h1]
[list]
[*]Es un juego de puzles que rompen la 4ta pared, además de tener cosillas de plataformero y amidakuji.
[*]Es complicado definir el gameplay sin ir a los spoilers, pero lo más básico es que el juego pide varias veces que busques información dentro de carpetas, menú de opciones, cuadros ocultos o listas de códigos. El juego siempre tendrá una salida, pero el encontrarlo es lo complicado y divertido. Algo por agregar es que el titulo hace muchas bromas a otros géneros de juegos y a la industria en general.
[*]Tiene pequeñas secciones de plataformero al mas puro estilo del dinosaurio de Google, un endless runner donde tendremos un poni, que adquirirá habilidades con pequeños desafíos por superar.
[*]También tenemos secuencias de amidakuji, que son niveles donde tendremos que guiar a un patrón que se desplaza hacia abajo, la idea es llegar al final con ciertos requisitos. Son algo fáciles, pequeñas distracciones a la locura que es la historia.
[*]Al terminar el juego podemos elegir capítulos para sacar los logros. También tenemos algunos coleccionables en forma de tickets, muy ocultos para sacarle todo el jugo a la experiencia.

[*]Ahora veamos algunos problemas:
-A veces si a veces no: Lo divertido del título (la búsqueda de información) puede ser un tanto confuso, a veces no es tan obvio, hay que tener mucho ojo en todo lo que hacemos. 
[/list]

[h1]+Gráficos: [/h1]
[list]
[*]Son impecables, sabe cómo engañar al jugador con su apariencia, además que le da un estilo visual muy único (al momento de romper la 4ta pared). 
[*]Un pequeño detalle es que el juego está adaptado para otra época, porque algunas bromas no se adaptaron del todo bien al Windows 10 o más.
[/list]

[h1]+Música y sonido: [/h1]
[list]
[*]Musicalmente no hay tonadas memorables, pero si hay momentos donde tensarte con música chiptune. Los sonidos también están en la misma categoría. 
[/list]

[h1]+Accesibilidad: [/h1]
[list]
[*]Tiene texto en español y otros idiomas.
[*]Se puede jugar con mouse, con algunas entradas para jugar con teclado. El juego te recomienda usar un mouse, el trackpad puede tener errores (ambos clics a la vez).
[*]El menú de opciones tiene una amplia gama de resoluciones. 
[/list]

-----
[h1]+En síntesis: [/h1]
[list]
[*]¿Podrás liberar tu alma del extraño juego Pony Island? Inténtalo, te sorprenderá lo maniobrero que es el título. Quien sabe que pasará con este mundo de ponis y su extraño lore detrás. Una primera gran joya de Daniel Mullins. 
[/list]

114545499.review:
Pony Island was one of the first games I spun for a new streaming schedule of mine, and honestly, it was a weird but strong foot to start on.

Let's start with the weak points, and there's only three:
1. The difficulty: It fluctuates, A LOT! Sometimes, it's a really easy thing, and other times it's confusing to all heck as how you're supposed to get through a section (Jesus Christ is making me cross).
2. The volume: It is LOUD. I had my headphones on half volume and my stream was turned down and it was still LOUD. The music and ambiance were frankly wayyyyy too loud at times.
3. The length: The length of the game kinda hurts my feelings towards it. It's a really short game, which shouldn't take you more than three hours, even if you are messing around and not very good at the game. But, that's okay considering the other good parts.

Now the meh stuff, and there's only one thing here:
The gameplay loop: It's honestly fun, but with the difficulty being fluctuating, it feels like it drags the game down a bit. But it's not bad, but it's not great. It's just, good.

Now the good stuff:
1. The Puzzles: The puzzles really are one of the shining points for this game. As short as they are and how like, scarcer they become, they're one of the strongest parts to this game because they're simple, but enjoyable. One of the strongest parts of the game by far.
2. The Secrets: The secrets are honestly not terrible. They're good in that they collecting of tickets is fun to figure out the weird things you need to do to get them. And that's not a bad thing. Certainly made me feel good when I managed tp figure different ones out.
3. The Story: The story is simple, and that's why it's good. It doesn't overstay it's welcome, and it's not overly complicated. I won't spoil it, but it's a really good story, and the gameplay compliments it really well.
4: The Music: It's honestly surprisingly good. Despite my gripes with the music being too loud, it's honestly quite good music. There's not a single track that I heard when playing the game where I thought "Ugh this music blows." GG to the composers. The electronic beats and general atmosphere really was quite good for each and every scene.

TL;DR
I'd rate this game a 3.5 out of 5 for it's merits and it's price point. I'd highly recommend getting this game in the Inscryption beginner bundle as it's more than worth getting at that price point. It's a good game with a few things that I didn't enjoy, but they seemed more personal to me. Overall: Good game, would recommend.

I do comment that if you choose to play this via trackpad, expect some difficulties and the game itself does not recommend this; and to add to that, there is some emphasis on fine mouse movement that I felt was a bit too high in terms of making the game fully accessible.

110427728.review: Fantastic little game! The gameplay itself is rather simple and when negative reviews describe it as repetitive and sometimes outright tedious, I can see where they're coming from. The eponymous "Pony Island" is an autorunner game where you jump over obstacles and attack approaching enemies - it never gets more complex than that. It's interfused with a "coding" game in which a cursor automatically steps through the program and you have to direct it towards the goal making sure necessary conditions are fulfilled. While that's clearly more demanding than piloting an autorunner, it's still fairly straightforward, most of all if you're used to more challenging puzzle games and know how to code. However, this game is brimming with unique ideas, cleverly hidden secrets and well-executed fourth wall breaks that made the entire experience incredibly enjoyable and worthwhile for me *despite* the objectively present repetitions. I felt repeatedly baffled. But bored? Not once!

Pony Island is short and sweet and certainly doesn't overstay its welcome. Despite the uneasy and unsettling atmosphere, I was pulled in enough to complete this in one sitting.

The trapped-in-a-video game premise is well done and the meta-game is fun to watch unravel as you play through.

The art style is great, and the soundtrack is a delight.

Well worth your time and money.

110330752.review: Pony Island is the debut work of Daniel Mullens. It's nothing absolutely groundbreaking, but sets the tone for what you can sort of expect from him. It is the tone of ARG's in the mid 2010's. Of fun little diversions from reality fleshed out to surprising degrees. It is at once novel and yet oddly nostalgic. It's certainly not the best game I've ever played, but it would be a lie to not say it was one of the well-made ones.

109824014.review:
UN JUEGO QUE ROMPE LA CUARTA PARED DE MANERA INCREÍBLE

 Pony Island es uno de los juegos mas extraños y bizarros que se puede jugar nunca. La razón de esto es que el juego nunca para de recordarnos que lo estamos jugando, y todos sus puzzles son resueltos de maneras poco convencionales que con creatividad pueden ser resueltos.

 De la historia simplemente no se puede hablar, porque el juego es demasiado corto y porque mientras menos sepas más la vas a disfrutar. Solo tienes que saber que, aunque no te pondrá emotivo, te sacará constantemente del comfort al que los videojuegos nos tienen acostumbrados, y esto lo hace único.

 Gráficamente, el juego tiene muy pocos píxeles, pero los efectos de distorción, el diseño de niveles y puzzles harán que realmente el juego se sienta como una pieza que jamás se repetirá.

 Su jugabilidad es maravillosa. Sus niveles de "acción" se sienten rítmicos y precisos, y cada uno de sus puzzles se siente extremadamente diferente al anterior. Jugar el par de horas que dura este juego te mantendrá enganchado de principio a fin, y un poco más.

 El apartado sonoro nos recuerda que estamos en un juego que, aunque no trata de horrorizarnos, nos perturba e incomoda constantemente con sus efectos oscuros y perturbadores. Tiene casi 2 canciones, pero ambas son excelentes y se sienten muy épicas, haciendo que las escenas de acción se sientan realmente como una aventura.

 Poco y nada se puede decir de Pony Island sin arruinarle la experiencia a alguien, pues vale muchísimo la pena. Si te llama la atención, simplemente cómpralo, sabiendo que lo normal es perturbarte y romper la cuarta pared como ningún otro juego ha hecho jamás.

109299946.review:
Okay let's start off by addressing what should be the obvious by now. It is one of those indie games that try to subvert your expectations about what it means to 'play a video game.' And by the by, I think it does it with marginal success. I really feel like to give this game justice, you have to go in blind and lower your expectations, which already isn't the best thing to say about it. But I say this as someone who genuinely enjoyed his time playing this game and (for some reason) teared up at the ending, this game doesn't know what it wants to do with itself. There are so many expectations and directions the premise and early game set up that I feel lead to dwindling results. And the ending result we do end up with is either really cool and meta, or just lame and flat. And I think that entirely depends on how much you think about what this game is doing and could have done. 

Just. Try not to think about it too much, or else you'll end up with probably a better version of the game in your head.

108420740.review:
This might be the most overrated game I have ever played, as well as the most misrepresented game by user reviews on steam. The game feels like it is trying to be clever, but it never left me feeling anything more than frustration for more than a few seconds. Pony Island gets a few things right, a few things that are a mixed bag, and the rest feels like a case of the developers thinking their you-know-what don't stink.

The Good

- The premise/idea is really cool (it should feel much more interesting than it ever fleshes out to be; complete wasted potential)
- The story occasionally has a few good (VERY fleeting) parts that engage for for a (VERY) brief duration

The Mixed Bag

- The puzzles are fine, nothing special but make you think; I have never done puzzles like these before
- The music fits for what the game is doing
- The price makes you feel less bad about having completed it; at only $5, you can't complain too much if you don't like it (and even more so on sale for liek $1.50). If it doesn't resonate with you (like it has festered with me) then it's not too big of a deal.

The Bad

- The game play is repetitive to a serious fault; many people would likely say that the game is designed to be this way due to what happens while you play. I think that is bullshit. If the game play is designed to be bad then the game play is bad, end of story. It MIGHT have been ok IF...
- The story goes nowhere and is a complete letdown. I was never truly engaged in what was happening, nor did I really care all that much. The game goes exactly where you think it will go; it surprised me exactly ONCE, and it was so short-lived as to be trivial. If the story had done something interesting, I MAYBE could have understood the game play being intentionally stupid. But it didn't. Do not expect anything as you go; there is no payoff, no reveal, NOTHING that you wouldn't expect.

If you don't mind spending a few bucks on something that might be a turd (like this) then feel free to ignore this. Otherwise, you can safely skip over Pony Island. It seems like a lot of people were willing to just eat up this pile of hot garbage that was developed thinking it was better than it truly was, but for me it was extremely disappointing.

107289515.review:
This is another one of those "I wish I could give a mixed rating" reviews.

Pony Island is a game with a couple of great ideas weighed down by a lot of tedium and an overarching story that frankly is not that compelling.

The idea of a video game created by the devil is extremely compelling, but annoyingly enough, most of the material based off of that concept are annoying and dated jokes which at least partially hinge upon the conceit that ponies are inherently funny subjects, as they are enjoyed by little girls. If you don't buy into the veritable comedy goldmine that is "pony humor," a big portion of the game will not land for you.

The gameplay itself also straddles the line between enjoyable and tedious. It's certainly fun to blast demons with your big pony laser, but after an hour or so of gameplay, you begin to realize that the core gameplay loop doesn't actually change all too much. You play as a pony, you jump over barriers, you rotate your head around with the mouse button and use your laser to kill things. Rinse and repeat.

 The big exceptions to this rule are the "coding puzzles" and game engine interaction (title screen, etc). I have nothing to complain about here, as with the exception of one very obnoxious puzzle at the end, these are uniformly enjoyable and should have been the bulk of the game. These are also the only sections in which you feel like you're in a real back-and-forth with the devil, which is very sad.

As for the story, it's passable. Your job is to break out of the devil's combination computer and arcade machine. The devil does not want you to do that, and would rather have you playing Pony Island forever. Antics ensue. There are a couple of "easter egg" areas which hint at a larger story, but you figure out exactly what that story is after only visiting a few of them. Again, it's not horrible, but nothing to write home about. The big issue is that the nitty-gritty of the plot is very hit-or-miss. Some parts of the experience are genuinely intriguing, while others are dull and should have been removed from the game completely. The third act in particular was almost entirely superfluous, unless, again, you're really really really into "pony humor." The best thing I can say is that the characters had some nice interplay, and that's it.

The big thing with Pony Island that everyone remembers are in the penultimate boss fight. It's definitely the highlight of the game, and depending on how accepting you are of the short time-frame they're present in, they may be worth the price of admission for you alone. I won't spoil anything, except [spoiler]that they're some of the first examples of the sort of gameplay present in a lot of later, more widely-acclaimed games--including Inscryption, which was created by the same developer and renders Pony Island *ALMOST* entirely obsolete.[/spoiler]

Other than that, there's not much to say. The music is good. The characters are all fine with one exception, who serves as another example of the dated humor in the game. The presentation, while not unique, is remarkably uncommon and serves the game well. It's simply a very middle-of-the-road experience, with the exception of the one boss fight I mentioned earlier.

Again, I wouldn't not recommend Pony Island. It's a short experience, and it's not a horrible one, so I can't in good conscience say not to buy it. I got it on sale and I don't regret the purchase. The game is hardly a must-play, though, and there's a lot of competition in its field. Buy it if it's on sale and you're okay with wasting about thirty minutes of your life jumping over hurdles.

Also, if you haven't yet, play Inscryption.

Deception.

From the moment you start a new game, you know you've been tricked. Most likely, you already knew the game was a trick.

This game goes deep, too. It plays on itself. It has secrets. Dark humor. Not so dark humor. Irony. Easter eggs.

106414760.review:
This review contains spoilers.


The first and likely only time I'm gonna not recommend a game with "Overwhelmingly Positive" reviews. In 2016 I remember seeing this game and thinking it was genius as did everyone else; but only seeing it through YouTube lets-plays.  Bought it recently out of reignited interest and it defiantly kept my interest at the start. But it rapidly deteriorated.  I don't know how you turn the concept of damnation disguised as an arcade boring, but they managed it. 
The gameplay is incredibly bland with some harsher mechanics thrown in every now and again to pretend like there is an upcurve in challenge that is never actually there.  It's a cycle of jumping and holding down right click. Then releasing right click to have the instantly-rechargeable laser bullshittery recycle so that you can spam it again. This is how all enemy encounters are. This is how the fight with fucking digital Lucifer goes. How do you make that uninteresting? I don't know. But they managed it. 

That's not the worst part in my opinion. The worst part is how the game views itself - thinking its way more clever then it actually is. Getting past the basic "WOAH!! I KNOW WHAT THE FOURTH WALL IS!" breaks, you get a barrage of unfunny, uninteresting and sometimes cringey dialogue. With a clear window of whoever writing it being full of themselves. At the same time, while taking itself too seriously the game manages to be disassociated from anything its talking about. You know how we were apparently asleep for over 300 years and absolutely nothing changed other then the start that degrades in 3 seconds? You know the guardian of the last core, the hyper-intelligent AI that just plays a mindgame with you for a moment and then says "yeah sure, you can now entirely ignore me. have the delete file for the third core"? Both of these things have great, great interest within them. They could be explored infinitely, and aren't. instead they're treated as either 3 lines of dialogue, or a shitty mindgame. 

This is a husk of a game. There is no substance. There's an interesting concept barely utilized. Perhaps at the time, this was a groundbreaking creation of meta games. An entirely new genre of games where it bleeds between the reality you live in as a player and the reality it has in store. But it's only been five years, and it's managed to drain any value it had. Do not buy these days unless its on sale and you have money to waste; but still be warry. Those two hours may feel like eight.

...The puzzles are cool though ig

[b]Pros:[/b]
-simplistic, clean gameplay
-extremely rewarding gameplay
-perfectly programmed game
-fair skill progression
-you can really see how much soul was put into this game
-but seriously, this is a fun meta-plot game that takes a simple premise and creates a really fun, mind-bending plot around it

[b]Cons:[/b]
-none whatsoever

[b]Overall:[/b] Pony Island is a game about a pony jumping over fences.  That's it.  That's all there is to it.

But seriously, the gameplay is crisp, simple and clean and manages to blend perfectly with the plot of the game, which is... not something you should want spoiled.  It's [i]wild[/i].  This is Daniel Mullins' first independently created game, followed by The Hex and Inscryption, both of which are also worth checking out.  The games all take place in the same "world" so to speak, and if you enjoy one, you'll probably enjoy all three.

If you haven't experienced anything Daniel Mullins has created, I would start with Inscryption.  If Inscryption is a little outside your price range right now, Pony Island is definitely worth the money and will show you what to expect.  Give it a shot, it goes on semi-regular sale for like a buck fifty.

[b]Bottom Line:[/b] Absolutely recommended.

105678769.review:
[h1] Aceptable [/h1]

Adquirí Pony Island en conjunto con Inscryption.

Después de disfrutar de la obra maestra que es Inscryption, me he visto en la obligación de jugar inmediatamente a los otros juegos del creador.

Y este primer juego de Mullins, sin ser para nada malo y resultando más que aceptable, no iguala a su moderno predecesor; cosa que es también normal, ya que Inscryption deja el listón a una altura estratosférica.

Lo del Pony es anecdótico. Bien podía haberse llamado Hamster Island o Crab Louse Island... Pues bajo el señuelo del entrañable equino, se esconde una propuesta interesante e inteligente, pero irrelevante el animal dado el desarrollo del juego, que resulta ser una taimada y artera ensalada de puzzles e ingeniosos quehaceres para resolver una profunda tesitura que entremezcla terror psicológico, moral y elementos informáticos, con ironía y cierta malevolencia (elementos brillantes en Inscryption).

El juego es muy breve. La primera partida la he acabado en 3 horas. Los logros no precisan más que otro par de horas para completarlo al 100%. En su corta duración Pony Island consigue dar cuenta de lo original y distinto que son los juegos de su creador comparados con el 99% de los juegos que hay en el mercado.

Lo cierto es que con muy poco, Pony Island es un juego diferente, que mostrará al jugador más pintado que, tantos años después del pistoletazo de salida de la industria, los videojuegos pueden ser algo más que aporrear botones o pasar fases una detrás de otra.

Una experiencia digna y muy recomendable, sin duda.

105492256.review:
It's fine. The actual 'gameplay' parts are honestly quite boring and annoying, but the parts in between are interesting and enjoyable. I do suppose that the mediocre gameplay is kind of the point considering who is the in-game developer.

Definitely enjoyable for the meta gameplay, but doesn't really stand out anymore considering games like Doki Doki Literature Club and I'm Scared have done this better. And as frustrating as some of Daniel Mullins other game 'The Hex' was, it really fleshed out a lot of his themes on game design, AI and meta mechanics compared to Pony Island. Maybe If I played Pony Island at the time of release I may have been more blown away by the meta gameplay and interesting mechanics.

Personally I would say that this game should be free, not because it is bad (which is isn't) but because it doesn't offer much anymore regarding the themes it centres around, and The Hex does almost everything better with a near identical theme: the story, characters, world building, length, meta mechanics, variety in gameplay, actual mystery. 
Also, being only around 2 hours long, Pony Island doesn't strike me as something worth paying for unless you specifically want to support Daniel and his team, which I wholeheartedly agree with.

If you want to give it a go you'll likely enjoy it and not regret your purchase. If you want to play a fully fleshed out game with almost the exact same themes, then just play The Hex or Doki Doki. But I'm still recommending this game since it is good in it's own right, just not £4 worth of content, maybe at the time of release but not anymore.

Now I will go back to playing Inscryption, since Daniel Mullins looks to be getting better and better as a developer every time he releases a game.

When I Stopped Playing: 
Completed, but not to 100%. I wasn't interested enough to try and get all collectables.

Rating:
7/10
Good ideas and a good prototype for Daniels more recent and more fleshed out games. Just not necessarily a great full game in it's own right.

105470982.review:
Pony Island is a B+. I came here *after* playing Inscryption and watching a Let's Play, which really isn't the best way to experience a Daniel Mullins game, but it's been long enough that the secrets are long since out. Even knowing what I was in for, it's an excellent mind-screw of a couple different genres. It can be beaten in just around two hours if just care about the plot and not the 100% run. I really like it.

The thing I've noticed about Inscryption and Pony Island is that Daniel Mullins WANTS you to beat the game. During the action scenes of Pony Island, you get plenty of subtle help if you die. For example, if you keep dying by falling onto gates, the gates VISUALLY stay the same but their HITBOXES get a little skinnier. Enemy attacks are the same way, where if you die to several projectiles, they might need to hit more than just your little pony rump in order to register as a hit. There are no direct "Difficulty Levels" per se, but it's clear Mullins wants gamers of all skill levels to be able to experience his story. Respect.

Inscrpytion made me a Daniel Mullins fan, and Pony Island just solidifies it. Now to play The Hex!

[h1]At-A-Glance:[/h1]
[b]Game type:[/b] Metafiction
[b]Genre(s):[/b] Surreal horror
[b]Art:[/b] Retro, 3D rendering, and glitch wrapped up into 8-bit and 32-bit arcade
[b]Length:[/b] Short (2-4 hours)
[b]Pace:[/b] Medium-paced
[b]Tags:[/b] Retro, surreal, metafictional, 
[b]Computer requirements:[/b] Medium-end


[h1]Notes:[/h1]
[olist]
[*] One of those "games about games" that is impossible to discuss without somewhat spoiling it. So, read this at your peril!
[*] A curious game where the actual act of playing itself isn't that "fun" - which is part of the point! (Again, impossible to talk about further without giving stuff away.) The actual points that the game is making (as well as lots of the jokes) are totally worth experiencing, which makes the lack of "fun" from the game itself feel like its own commentary.
[*] Some of the story elements are awesome, and others are tacked on and weird. [spoiler]So you're a 13th-century Crusader who got killed and added into a video game purgatory? .... Okay? [/spoiler] And on the other hand, [spoiler]metafictional video game hell that spoofs your Steam inbox and makes a statement about game design itself? Amazing.[/spoiler] It's like the [i]NES Godzilla[/i] creepypasta turned into a game - both the good and the bad bits.
[*] The hacking puzzles are great, though a certain aesthetic switch later on makes them ironically more abstract than in the pure ASCII-text of the first and last thirds of the game.
[*] Extremely reminiscent of stuff like "The Stanley Parable" and "Undertale" in both humor and approaches to metafictional games. I don't think this is as good as those (too many of the aforementioned story beats that don't really gel with anything else, and not in the good-schizoid way of most surreal fiction). And, it's still worth checking out for fans of games and games-as-games.
[/olist]

103381274.review:
Unicorn Surprise Cupcakes!

INGREDIENTS
mixing bowl
24 cupcake cases
cupcake tins
a piping bag and nozzle
four eggs
250g caster sugar
390g butter
250g self-raising flour
1 tsp vanilla essence
1 tsp baking powder
290g icing sugar
one block of white regal icing
food colourings of your choice
decorations of your choice
sweets – small ones work best

HOW TO MAKE THEM
1. Beat 250g of butter and the caster sugar together until light and fluffy, then add the flour to the bowl and mix well. Beat in the eggs, vanilla essence, food colouring and baking powder. Once it’s thoroughly combined, place the mixture into the cupcake cases. Bake in the oven at 180°C (gas mark four) for about 20 minutes. They should be springy to the touch and a light golden colour. Transfer them to a wire rack to cool.

2. To make the buttercream icing, combine the icing sugar with the remaining butter. Add a few drops of vanilla essence and a food colouring of your choice. Once mixed, place in the fridge to chill until you’re ready to use it.

3. While the cakes are cooling, you can start to make the decorations. Take the regal icing and split in half. Add a few drops of food colouring to one half, then knead the icing until the colour is evenly distributed.

4. Take a small amount of each of the pieces of icing – about the size of a large pea – and gently roll them out into two thin sausage shapes.

5. Place the rolled out icing sausages next to each other, then twist them round each other, pinching one end to form the tip of the unicorn horn. Repeat steps three and four until you have one unicorn horn per cupcake.

6. To make the ears, take the uncoloured icing and make two balls of equal size – they should each be roughly the size of a small marble.

7. Take one of the balls and, using your thumb and index finger, mould the icing into the shape of a small pony ear. Repeat until you have two ears per cupcake.

8. Once the cakes are completely cool, use a knife to cut a small circle in the top of them. Remove the top, and cut off any excess until just a small disc remains. Fill the cupcake with sweets, then place the disc back on the cake. Repeat until all the cakes are filled.

9. Remove the buttercream from the fridge and spoon into the piping bag. Swirl the icing onto the cake in a spiral, finishing with a peak in the centre.

10. Place a horn in the centre of the cake with an ear on either side, pressing them firmly in place. Then add your choice of decoration – you could even use edible glitter to add a bit of sparkle!

102302119.review:
The game's main mechanic is breaking the 4th wall, and it kind of ran out of steam for me after it makes its first reveals.  It clearly is really effective for some, but it just left me feeling a bit bored.  

I should preface this by saying I tend to prefer games with a bit more mechanical meat to them, but I do love games with a good story.  But I never felt like Pony Island had either.  The idea of a cursed children's game sounds interesting, but it quickly lost its charm for me after its first big, "I know I'm game, you are at my mercy wooOOooOoo" moments, which happens fairly early on.  I'm not sure why this is, it is more of a puzzle / visual novel game which is defo outside my comfort zone, but if I had to guess the culprit - it was probably the writing.  

I never felt myself immersed due to some really awkward dialogue and ironically the 4th wall breaks, with the attempted creepiness of breaking the game usually just serving to remind me I'm only looking at 1's and 0's.  I never connected to the narrative, and I wasn't interested to see it go forwards because it never sold itself to me as more than a video game.  This is coming from someone who gets attached to his X-COM characters too, so I CAN be immersed into games.  

I think the tonal dissonance the game tries to create with its premise is interesting and could be expanded further in a game that uses it with more restraint, but I don't think it works on someone like myself.  I didn't like Doki Doki Literature Club for similar reasons.  This is still a wildly creative and unique game, but it certainly wasn't for me.

102177769.review:
I don't recommend this game. The game is from the creater of the new game inscryption. Since one of his previous games was on sale and had good reviews, I wanted to check it out.

The game features 3 different gameplays and a storyline breaking continously the 4th wall.

First and main mechanic is an endless runner. This was not a lot of fun. At the beginning, it's too easy. Later on, it becames a little challenging, but not in a fun way.
Second mechanic is solving puzzles by putting direction arrows in code. This is not much fun and just clicking. Only the very last of these section required actual thinking.
The third mechanic is about clicking through the desktop of a computer, advancing the plot and finding secret tickets. Finding all tickets results in a different ending. Findings the secret tickets was the best part for me, but it's probably not for everyone and can occur to people as tedious.

I can't recommend this game because none of the gameplay elements were particularly fun. I did not get any enjoyment out of this game. Again, this is not because it's an indie game or the graphics are very simple. Skip this game.

As for a recommendation, if you like an indie puzzle game with simple graphics, try "Steven's sausage roll". The puzzles start as cute and move up to extremely challenging and clever.

102006562.review:
Pony Island is a place of sunshine and rainbows, where ponies gallop cheerfully through grassy hills and play with the beautiful butterflies, and try not to be tickled by the butterflies, or the ponies will laugh heavily in joy. You befriend the other ponies and race off towards the big blue skies where nothing can stop you, and you will smile and cry out with cheerfulness as you run on the rainbows. It is a dreamland to frolic around in and filled with beautiful days that never see gray clouds. Or, is there something more? Was that the game you were expecting?

What lies in Pony Island is a dark, disturbing yet intriguing world where you and the souls of other players of Pony Island are trapped inside the arcade machine, doomed to remain until eternity. You are property of the devil. You are not free. That is, until one brave, mysterious soul offers you the chance to be freed. When the opportunity arises, destroy the core files of the arcade cabinet, and all can be freed. The devil will persuade you and trick you not to take such actions. He will go out of his way to stop you. All he wants is to keep your soul in the hellscape that is Pony Island. 

Unique visuals, smart puzzles, a mysterious story, and a heavy, dark atmosphere make Pony Island a short, yet a thrilling and unforgettable experience. The Devil will toy with you, and break the fourth wall to do so. He is not toying with some playable character, but he's messing with *you*. Do not listen to the Devil. He lies. He always lies.

100282229.review:
A game that completely enrages me, and then has me immediately attempt the same level I just almost passed before a surprise! :D 

Seriously, though this is a simple and fun game. The best way to describe this doozy is: Side-scroller meets puzzle game meets creepy game.

This is a very short game, which is good because it does feel like it over-stays its welcome. The levels and puzzles are the same things over and over again - but not in an agonizingly long, stupid story. 

It's quick - the characters are just interesting enough to say hello and goodbye, and the gameplay environment is okay for atmosphere... very FNAF feel to the 'setting'. 

If you like quick games with a short premise. easy to medium puzzles, and a classic side-scroller, look no further! It's 5 bucks, which isn't bad -- but if you can get it on sale, do so! 

Replay value is.. meh.. as you really want to wait until you do another run to find hidden tickets because it can get so monotonous. 

You really know what you're going to get after the first few levels. After ACT I it feels more the same, just with more annoying attributes (Don't hit X, while jumping over posts, while trying to fly and shoot - but remembering not to hit the X, otherwise you start over again).

I am not proud to say I rage-quit this game the other night because I couldn't get it together. 

7/10, have been playing again to find secrets!
